title: Wondrous

author: Beach reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review_content: Great plot with constant twists and turns. I not only enjoyed it as a page-turning read, but I got a lot of great role-modeling out of the hero who tackles problems ad infinitum. I seriously did, I'm sure I'll think back on what-would-Ryland-Grace-do? next time I'm in a pickle. I loved his process and his way of going for broke on life-threatening decisions. I kept thinking about that line from the Martian movie -- "There will be problems, and if you solve enough problems you will get to go home." I felt inspired for this space journey called life!
title: Enjoyable AND inspiring

author: Doud_FtC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: I’m only 70 pages into an almost 500 page novel, but there are already some issues that don’t jive. In The Martian and this novel, the author appears to use physics to help the protagonist unravel their conundrum. In this one it helps him (maybe a she in a future book?) determine that gravitational acceleration is too high for earth and it cannot be a centrifuge. But,1. By giving the mass and diameter of an Astrophage we find that its density (mass per unit volume) is approximately 4% of an Earth microorganism, that is, either much lighter compounds than water or a lot of empty space, except2. Puncturing an Astrophage reduces it to a blob of goop, implying it’s a liquid which isn’t consistent with its density, and3. Finding that the Astrophage is (chemically at least) mostly water. It’s also annoying that the volume of one Astrophage is so small (500 femto-liter or 0.5 times ten to the minus twelve liters) that no existing or planned analytical instrument could determine its composition.The witty repartee between the protagonist and ESA overlord is nice, but not realistic. So, engaging story line but please dot the i’s and cross the t’s.
title: Weir makes me grumpy

author: Christine Rolfes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: Any fan of The Martian will be a fan of Project Hail Mary. I loved how this story unfurled--petal by petal and still what was inside surprised and amazed me. The topics and challenges that the main character encounters, and of course, how he deals with them feel like a heart-stopping race to very end. Despite the apocalyptic future that spurs the story's beginning, there are plenty of moments that made me laugh, ponder, and explode with curiosity. This is as exciting as any "What if...?" book out there. I'll definitely read it again.
title: Could not stop reading!

author: Tropics
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: If you liked the tech of The Martian you will love this story. As with The Martian I was not sure if I liked it or not so kept reading....and suddenly found it was 2AM. I enjoyed it. I am not a big fan of flashback but in this story it worked. Andy Weir knocked another one out of the park (or should I say solar system?
title: p ).

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: Science and the scientific method work on a scale of decades and centuries-- they build up a foundation on which inventions can grow.  The most spectacular of inventions take years to effect society in meaningful ways.  Andy comes up with situations where science is quick, exciting, and dangerous.  Like McGyver was to engineering, his protagonists are to science.  They hypothesize, test, deal with the consequences of being wrong, and repeat.My high school physics class we had was not taught by an inspirational figure.  Physics wasn't his thing.  He would actually have us grade each other's work.  We would then step through the solutions and note the correct answers.  In real physics, partial credit is key-- we never know the answer completely-- the important parts are in how we go about solving the problem.  Our teacher didn't understand this.There may be a technical issue or two with a small fraction of the science in Project Hail Mary.  That isn't the point.  The point is that his story might inspire critical thinkers to engage science and to dream about how their work can contribute to the survival and betterment of humanity.  So yes, 19/20, Andy Weir.
title: Again, Andy comes up with a scenario to make science exciting.

author: Nomadic Reviewer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2021
review_content: I am a lover of good quality science fiction and was not disappointed and although,I may not understand all the science, astronomy or physics stuff, I know a good story line. I think if you read the Martian, then you’re bound to enjoy Hail Mary. Mr. Weir’s humor is prevalent throughout, adding just the right amount to make this read far more enjoyable.  George, John, Ringo and Paul were by far my favorite aspects and brought the blend of science, music and songs to make a harmonious and delightful Spring read.
title: Science Meets Songs

author: Chuckwrite
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: I truly enjoyed ‘The Martian’ and ‘Artemis’ and this one started out just as good. I considered myself well educated, even into biological science, but I’m not a physicist.  Most of it is a good and exciting story, so maybe some readers may need to skim through the physics lesson. If you start, don’t just quit. The rest of the story will be worth your time.
title: Great story but lost in the details

author: BGK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: Best book I’ve read in 20 years, and I read constantly. I liked the first two books a lot, but this one had so many other facets. I admit I skimmed some of the science details, but it was the story itself that made this so memorable. You don’t have to love science to love this book. Don’t let the first academic references deter you. Great characters, interesting writing style, and it made the impossible sound feasible. The ending was unexpected and I loved it. I’d give it a six if that were an option.
title: Destined to be a classic, and can’t wait for the movie! 🤞🏻

author: Thomas K. Parrent
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2021
review_content: I thought Andy Weir’s “The Martian” was outstanding. Certainly the best science fiction book I’d read in decades.This. Is. Better.Really knocks it out of the solar system in his third novel.As each problem appears, you realize he has given you just enough information to figure out the source of the problem and it's solution. So it's part sci-fi, part mystery, part do it yourself spaceship repair.Propel yourself at light speed to your nearest bookseller.
title: Weir keeps getting better!

author: M. Marchand
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: Not sure where to go with this review because I don't want to give away plot twists. This is about as far-out imaginative as someone can get with a hard science fiction novel. Weir's research on all science-related topics is thorough and spot on. I loved The Martian, and hated his second book. This, his third, rises to the level of Martian.
title: Stick with it - it's worth it

author: Kimberly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: I read this at the urging of a friend who was reading it. I had read The Martian and loved that, so I was pretty confident going in. I was not prepared for how much I loved this book. I cannot remember the last time I was so excited about a book that I stayed up late reading it or read passages out loud for my significant other. What a fantastic journey. This was even better than The Martian. Loved the plot, the characters, the suspense, and the humor. A terrific read. Highly recommend.
title: Absolutely Awesome

author: J. Robbins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2021
review_content: The only thing I didn’t like about this book was that it had to end. I enjoyed the characters, the unusual storyline, the interesting science stuff, and the writing style.If you loved The Martian, this one will grab you immediately too. I read it in 2 days, only taking a break to get some sleep.I won’t give away any details of the story, just that it’s got a great main character and a story that will keep you turning the pages eagerly to see what happens next.
title: Another page-turner from Weir

author: Peter J. Neame
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: Very science-heavy, so may not appeal to all. However, underlying the science is a an outstanding science fiction first contact story (actually two first contact stories). And underlying that is a wonderful story of friendship and respect. The ending was fabulous.All-in-all a feel-good book with just enough "what did happen with.... " to leave the reader happy and curious witout being too frustrated. I enjoyed the authors first book quite a bit. This is like that on steroids.

author: Weekly Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2021
review_content: Supposedly I read over 60 books last year.  This book is better than any of those . author: Alice Byrd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: 5 stars because it feels like sitting down by a fireplace in a den with Andy while he spins this fabulous story for you. I am nowhere near a scientist but i love reading about these interstellar space  travel adventures. Characters are well developed with some nurturing close and tender relationships with each other,while others are deliciously contentious.I loved the Martian,was entertained by Artemis,but was blown away by the edge of your seat plot in Hail Mary.
title: Suspenseful,tender and witty read , highly recommend

author: Sheraz Choudhary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: This is probably the best Science Fiction book I have read!  The concept behind the story is so interesting and the book is well written.  I don't know how Andy came up with this but it is brilliant.I would have to be super picky to even try to find something that wasn't perfect.  A story has to have problems for the characters to solve so lots of things have to go wrong and then get solved.  This makes the story less realistic but it is also essential to write an engaging book.
title: Just Excellent!!!

author: Joe Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: Took me four days to read, but only because work and sleep got in the way.  Excellent read for anyone with two neurons to rub together.  Just for the science aspects explained in a plain English, engaging way, it should be required reading for every eighth grader.  But, the G rating does not distract from a great reading "buddies" book with messages more powerful than xenonite.  Messages that the people of the world need to hear loud and clear.  In many ways, a timely read.
title: Very stemulating

author: D. J. Bershaw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: Should someone visit John W. Campbell's grave, he wouldn't be there. Instead, he would be with Andy Weir, smiling, laughing, and nodding his head. The Martian was, but this book will be tougher to translate to the screen. Artemis will be easier. Rocky is a superior alien by any standard. Simply wonderful.

author: melissa meserve
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021

author: CODY C

review_content: Great fun book with lots of science quips like the Martian, which is great. Mostly from a single point of view. author: Kindle Customer

review_content: At first I thought I caught the hint of a "Martian" vibe but the story goes way beyond a guy left on a planet in our solar system. author: golota82

author: Eric H. Read

author: R. Song

author: Aneil

review_content: I wasn’t sure whether I would like this latest novel, as I really didn’t like Andy Weir’s second book, Artemis. author: Kindle Customer

review_content: I started this on a Wednesday morning because I needed something to read next and I enjoyed The Martian and Artemis. author: Always Already

This book WILL BE a movie within the next two years and I will be sitting front row middle watching.  I took twice as long reading this as I normally would because I was savoring every chapter. author: Roger Duke
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Couldn’t put it down. Didn’t want it to end.It’s once in a few years that we get a gem like this one. My favorite read since Wool and Three Body Body Problem series. title: Even better than The Martian!

author: Katie N. Harper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2021
review_content: The book starts out grabbing the reader quickly. There is a lot of mystery and awe and quite a sense of wonder, that the author maintains nicely, until...about midway: the wonder becomes somewhat ho-hum. There were plot twits and challenges to be met, but not much in the way of suspense. The problems were solved almost too easily. It reads more like young adult fiction ("hungry as heck"? Gosh darn this or that...) It is not that real characters need to use foul language, but this just sounded trite to me.
title: Young Adult Fiction?

author: Personal Touch Jewelry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed the opportunity to read another book by Andy Weir. The plot sounded exciting and I started reading it immediately. I didn’t enjoy the main character a lot. His “oh golly, gosh dialogue got old quickly. Mr. Weir did an excellent job of creating an ordinary person but I like a more alpha personality. I don’t want to give any of the plot away I will just say that it is a very good book just not what I was expected.
title: Not quite what I was expected.

author: Jim Kukral
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: I don't understand one bit of all the sciency stuff, at all, but I believe it and for some reason it intrigues me to read it. Maybe it helps that I know Andy isn't making it up because he's a legit nerd? Don't know. It just works. Really enjoyed Hail Mary. His characters have such great humor and humanity in them. I would love to see him write an anti-hero in his next endeavor. I feel he could really pull that off. Great book.
title: Great follow up to my favority scyfy writer

author: Kent L. Weitkamp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: The Martian left me speechless, this work left me breathless from start to finish. The science is beyond entertaining - it’s an education that you didn’t know you needed and can’t wait to continue on the next page. The characters don’t offer much depth but there performance is magical (that’s science beyond my understanding). I can hardly wait for the next volume from Andy Weir to take me where I didn’t know I needed to go.
title: Wow - Didn’t Think Andy Weir Could Get More Creative

author: Brian Soper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Project Hail Mary is a science fiction novel grounded in as much scientific accuracy and realism as possible for a novel with a plot involving alien life.  This novel is much more in the vein of Weir's first novel "The Martian", and readers who enjoyed that novel should thoroughly enjoy this one as well.  The personalities and interpersonal interactions were very convincing, and the use of flashbacks to to slowly give the reader (and Grace) the background information they so desperately want was very well done.  Highly recommended to all lovers of science fiction books, it is very enjoyable, even if much of the math and technical explanations go over your head.
title: Great science fiction novel.

author: James T. Peeples
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: If you love science fiction where the science is based in plausibility and is well-considered, consistent with itself, and well-integrated into the story, you'll love this book.On the other hand, if you love science fiction with well-developed characters and an immersive plot, well, you'll still love this book.Best damn science fiction novel I've read in the last two decades.  Strongly recommended.
title: One of the best "hard" science fiction novels I have ever read.

author: Mark B. Hazelbaker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: Easily one of the best fiction books I’ve read in years. It is rooted in hard science, with some completely credible speculative biology that drives the plat. But there is no magic, just the same kind of relentless research and Hardwork that saved Mark Watley on Mars. This book has some compelling characters, humorous moments, and is destined to abuse and entertaining uplift a lot of people for many years. A must read.
title: A Delight!  Fascinating and Satisfying

author: Tiger Frank
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: I was mesmerized by the plot and the science behind this novel ! Weir is a master story teller and space nerd ! If the loved the Martian, this is even better ! Don't wait but it now ! Can't wait until the make the movie , ET will be history !
title: Great read ! One of the best science fiction novels of all time !

author: Queen Meega
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: Project Hail Mary by Andy Weir is his third novel. This time Earth itself is in trouble and the entire world has to come together to formulate a solution. The hero in this story, Dr. Grace, has the same sarcastic sense of humor we loved in the Martian.  The discovery of alien life, the descriptions of how people and governments would behave and the science discoveries all seem realistic.  Well worth your time.
title: A buddy comedy with aliens

author: Luke J. Callaghan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: This book was amazing.  I’d even go so far as to say it was better than The Martian.  (Maybe.  I haven’t quite made up my mind).  Everything about it was exciting and it really lit the fire for me to read more often—not a thing I can say about many books.The only bad thing I can say is that there seems to be a lot of deus ex machina, where some problems which I thought would be a bigger deal sort of just get solved in a few pages.  This especially happens when the main character is suddenly able to remember convenient things at convenient times.  Or how, in the later parts, the main character is basically able to 3D print any object of the strongest material (un)known to man, in no time at all and with no effort.  It can just become a little unrealistic.  Yet, with a page count pushing 500, I guess some concessions needed to be made.Other than those few, minor complaints, this is an amazing book, and, after the slight dip in quality after with Artemis, I’m ecstatic that Weir is back on track.  I’m looking forward to the next one.
title: Fantastic book

author: E.J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: Like the Martian, this is a fun romp. I couldn’t finish Artemis, but the reviews said that Weir had returned to form — and he has. To avoid spoiling the story, I’ll just say that it features a wise cracking protagonist and a series of problems he must solve to save the human race. I couldn’t put it down and finished it in two days. The most fun I’ve had reading a book in a long time. I highly recommend it!
title: Fun read — Andy Weir is back

author: Ron5714C
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: Five stars is not near enough--maybe TEN STARS would be more like it.  For science fiction this is about as real as you can get. And it even makes science sensible and approachable. That is all in addition to great characters and approachable aliens (distant relatives maybe?). Imagine a cowardly hero who saves not  one but two planets in solar system light years apart. Imagine a singing alien that looks like a horny crab with five legs, and can't see. Wonderful. I hated to finish it!
title: TEN

author: Alex
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: Another hit, I highly recommend.  This one has more noble themes like The Martian, but introduces many elements that are definitely invented, which I really enjoyed because the delivery is very sciency and technical making it slightly more believable than so many books that explain away stuff we cannot do today like faster than light travel in a couple hand wavey sentences. Can't wait for the next one!
title: Yup it's really good

author: real book reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: The book was well written especially with all the science but  I found the amount of science in the plot slowed me down too much.  Much of the plot seemed drawn out. I wont give plot spoiler.I appreciated The Martian storyline more as it was for science fiction " believable " and characters made sense.I gave a 3 star as science fiction buffs will like the science probably more than I did.
title: Project Hail Mary

author: Dane E. Ericksen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
review_content: I thought that Weir's book The Martian and the move by the same name were outstanding.  Now Weir has outdone himself with Hail Mary, and I see it is going to be made into a movie, as well.  Love Weir's writing style.  Intelligent science fiction.  This is the best science fiction novel I have ever read, and I had read a lot.  Clever but credible developments through out.  Treat yourself to this book.
title: Outstanding science fiction novel

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I devoured "The Martian" in one sitting, read "Artemis" before the end of the same week, and pre-ordered this book as soon as I knew about it. So let's say I'm an Andy Weir fan. Yeah, that's accurate.He's a rare talent. It doesn't really matter if you're a sci-fi fan or not, his books are dense  yet accessible, with crackling dialogue, vivid imagery and complete plausibility.Loved it.
title: Enthralling....

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review_content: Not quite as compelling as The Martian, but much better than Artemis. Sometimes it gets bogged down with scientific jargon, but it is a fast read because the life of the earth, and of the protagonist are at stake. A science teacher is drafted to become part of a team of astronauts who must save the earth when the sun dims. Add in a strange alien who becomes a charming character, and it's a recipe for suspense.
title: Outer space suspense

author: beajerry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2021
review_content: Wow!  This is the best sci fi book I’ve read in a long time, since Stephenson’s Seveneves, since Weir’s first book, The Martian.Weir’s second book was enjoyable, but kinda forgettable.This one is a blast, just like The Martian: lots of science and science problems to work out (may be a little tedious  though for non-science people, but then why would they be reading sci fi in the first place?).Great use of flashbacks and a severely interesting premise, then add to that a surprise friend.The ending might be hokey, but satisfies in a classic sci fi way. And you can see a movie definitely coming pretty quick.The content reminded me in general of Arthur C. Clarke.A good, comfortable sci fi romp.
title: Great Classic Sci Fi !

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: I enjoyed Weir's The Martian and picked this up when a friend told me it was out. Project Hail Mary draws you in from the first page and keeps your interest page to page and chapter to chapter until its surprising and satisfying end. Sure there's a lot of science, but Weird explains it so well that we all feel like scientists by the end. If it weren't for work, I would have finished in two days, but three days is fine too. Recommended escapism fun!
title: Fast and fun

author: Violet Crumbles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: I could hardly put it down! It *is* very sciencey, but remains highly readable, engaging, exciting and heartwarming. You will definitely make a new friend (maybe two). And few books surprise me anymore, but this one did.
title: You need to take this trip

author: S. Demarest
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: This is an enjoyable read for the nerd in you.  It doesn't ask much of the reader.  The "I can figure this out or fix it" spirit of the protagonist is very similar to The Martian, as he Maguyvers his way around.  The ending is very Heinlein-like.  I wouldn't mind seeing some real character development, and I sort of feel like the more interesting story may have been the whole world coming together to launch the Hail Mary mission. There's zero romance... just a tiny bit of back story.  4 stars is a bit of a stretch, but not much - I expected a Martian-like experience and the Author met my expectations.
title: Reads Like The Martian

author: Konrad Skrzypek
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I liked this book. And I really wanted it to be good. Martian good perhaps. But it is lacking something - it reads better than Artemis, it has better story, deeper characters, but still it's more a computer adventure game than a book. And it's a educational game too. I'd venture a guess here - Weir is Weir. He's not a great story teller, his books will probably always be choke full of scientific information, crises and likeable science guys who science the $..t out of them. But at the end of a day I stil had fun reading it.
title: It's not bad...

author: Kindle Customer Ilian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I recommend this book to anyone who can read!  First of all, Andy Weir  can really write well and his prose is easy to read.  Second, the plot of this book is well thought out  and engaging ;  I found it hard to put it down (and now have a LOT of responsibilities to catch up on).  And the human/Eridian relationship was touching withhout becoming maudlin.  What an imagination Mr. Wait has!  I guarantee no-one with Amy seitivity
title: Just A Real Joy

author: Clifford Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: Heinlein wrote stories like this. Of space travel and solving problems. Working through the implications of his characters’ tough situations and rarely resorting to hand-wavery to get them out. The self-reliant lead character in Hail Mary is likable, smart, and cool headed. The technology for interstellar travel is the same thing that threatens to destroy the solar system. Figuring out how to use the problematic stuff to solve the actual problem is delightfully meta. Highly recommended.
title: Feels like RAH

author: George V. Neville-Neil
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: Maybe it's unfair to compare this with the Martian but they have similarities in style that really cannot be denied.  Science and engineering challenges along a narrative that keeps you engaged and all written with a positive humanity that had once all but disappeared from Science Fiction during the period of constant dystopias.  Not sure how many different ways Weir can slice this type of narrative but I'll happy try the next one such that he comes up with.
title: Another great arc

author: CHUL HWAN JUNG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Hmm... I don't think it's a novel that surpasses his first work, Martian. The scale has gotten much bigger and the storyline has gotten more complicated, but... I got bored because too many parts were included in the science experiment part in narrative style, and given that it is a novel without pictures, I should easily imagine the scene in my head as I read it. That's not possible. In fact, there are many things that are impossible to imagine.  I was expecting a lot because it was published in 30 countries at the same time... but the story is interesting and the idea is good. Now~~ I'm looking forward to how this will turn this into a movie. Rather, it might be a better material than'Martian' for a movie...
title: Fresh, interesting storyline... but little bit boring..

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2021
review_content: The novel was not funny and has sequences that seemed to serve to only extend the story. The ending was not good. Don't be afraid to write a negative review because you, like me, loved the Martian and Artemis.
title: Comments from a reader

author: Missy Boone
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: Very long but not long enough,, a lot of technology but so enjoyable,, bought the Kindle version and ended up listening to it on my Amazon Show as audible,, I bounced from car Bluetooth to the Show for 3 days,, ALL day,, days!!! The narrator was fantastic, my 12 year old grand daughter got in on it about a fifth of the way through,, sad to see it go,, great book!!!
title: I LOVED IT

author: Matthew Kerwin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: The third novel from This author. Much like The Martian, it’s a gripping story of man vs nature. From the opening puzzle to the final twist it held my attention and was hard to put aside.The science is well researched and believable. This is not a science fantasy novel, be prepared to read many pages about a guy doing math in the current story and in flashbacks. Despite that, the characters are relatable in both timeframes and their escalating problems ensure it never gets boring.
title: Gripping and hard to put down

author: Frankster
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: It’s been awhile since I found a book that I couldn’t put down, but this book broke that streak. From the first pages I was drawn in. This book had twists and turns I didn’t see coming, moments that were horribly dire but I found myself laughing from the dialogue. Do yourself a favor and transport yourself with Grace and his unlikely friend on an epic, trans world journey.
title: Fantastic

author: Becky B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: Weir has returned to his science nerdy best with this story of an unlikely astronaut on the hunt for a way to stop a microbe threatening the entire solar system. I liked it just as much if not more than The Martian (we'll just pretend Artemis never happened), and I liked that there's significantly less swearing since the main character is a school teacher.
title: Science nerd fun

author: quietcatly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: Don’t start reading this book in the evening or be ready to let go of sleep that night. It’s deliciously nerdy. Every detail is thought of. If you ever wondered how a life form would exist that isn’t based on carbon, you have your answer here. The calculations and the science might tire some, but for a professor of engineering it was awesome. Absolutely awesome.
title: Goldmine for geeks

author: Adelle Curtis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I loved The Martian.  I enjoyed Artemis.  This one is AMAZING!  Not what I expected.....in all the best ways.  I won't bore you with a plot synopsis but don't dig TOO deep....part of the fun is not knowing where the story will go.Weir's other books have had a TON of strong language.  This one doesn't.  I found that a welcome change.  And it was believable for the character.
title: Must read!

author: John F. O'Halloran
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2021
review_content: The main character awakened with no memory of where he is or even who he is. As he explores the space he is in, he figures out where he is and slowly regains his memory. He is alone... but for how long?Mr Weir crafts great characters, works hard to get the science right, and his info dumps are well done and do not come across as lectures.
title: Another great hard SF novel from Andy Weir

author: LN
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2021
review_content: And I read all three of them.If The Martian is meticulously and unnecessary detailed, Artemis catching but essentially empty book (again, full of needless trivialities), Project Hail Mary hits the bull's-eye: an interesting plot, solid and knowledgeable writing, and, of course, Andy Weirs's signature "duct tape" (keep it real) science fiction.
title: This is his best novel so far.

author: Jonny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: Yes, yes it is. In all seriousness, this is a contender for one of my favorites I've read in recent memory.  I'd consider it a must read for any real science fiction fan.  Unfortunately, any details I give about why i feel that way would be spoilers, and its best to go into it knowing nothing.  So, if you are a sci-fi fan, just buy it and dive in.
title: Is this the best book ever, question?

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: Yep, again a lone astronaut in space against seemingly unsourmontable odds. But this time, instead of saving himself, he must find a solution for a problem which, if left unchecked, will lead to the total extinction of humankind.And, he manages to get help from the most unlikely of quarters.GREAT read, I can't wait for the movie to come.
title: 'The Martian' on super-steroids

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: like The Martian, Hail Mary features a persevering scientist facing one tense situation after another. I don't want to spoil the many plot twists, but let's say there is humor and a thoroughly unexpected twist at the end. One of the blurbs describes the book as "propulsive," and it is. Well plotted, interesting characters, and satisfying science fiction.
title: Two for two!

author: Zachary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review_content: The mix of science, intrigue, and emotion that Andy Weir brings to his books is incredible, and Hail Mary does it again.
title: Another great

author: Renee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2021
review_content: Page turner from the beginning. How imaginative Andy Weir is with Rocky! I giggled out loud. I cursed out loud and my heart banged in my chest on one particular EVA. I even learned some science along the way.We loved The Martian as a movie but then my son told me to read the book. I loved it more than the movie (of course). When this book came out my husband got it it for me. I have since bought 2 more of his books. Thank you, Mr Weir!
title: I don’t like sci-fi but I loved this

author: BlackOutBrian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: If you enjoy space and science, you’ll enjoy this book. I’d rank Andy’s books like this:1) Project Hail Mary2) The Martian3) ArtemisI had a tough time putting it down. While I was reading it, I really just felt amazed by the world the author created. Can’t wait to see what Andy comes up with next.
title: My favorite sci-if book in a long time!

author: COL Ron
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
review_content: I have enjoyed the author’s prior 2 books. This book had so much minutia that I would lose interest and stop reading for a while before I could restart where I left off. The premise was fairly interesting but the characters really failed. They just were not believable.I hope the next book moves faster and the characters are more likable
title: The 3rd book

author: Will Wilson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: Short version… it’s another “the world is ending, but we’ve found a way to fling people into space and, hopefully, solve the problem” kind of book. If you like that genre and you like the kind of story where random problems pop up and they have to science a way out of it, then this ones for you. It’s not boring. It’s not going to make you ponder the meaning of existence in any way. I’d say it’s a guilty pleasure sci-fi story. I don’t regret buying it at all, but it’s not the best book I’ve ever read. I don’t want to be the reason someone doesn’t read it, so I’ll leave the negative aspects to someone else.
title: It’s not a waste of money

author: Lynder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I loved the book and thought the ending was creative.  Andy Weir has a great way of explaining complicated things while ensuring it adds to the story in a great way.  He's able to make his characters relatable with comedic relief and you can't help but feel for them.  loved the problem and solution. Looking forward to another book!
title: Amazing!

author: Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: This book as everything you expect from Andy Weir and more. You’ll get lots of math, jokes, and some heart string tugs. I can’t say enough about this book. Just get it!
title: Just buy it.

author: Pete12345
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review_content: Each of Weir's three books has been great. In my opinion, each new book has been better than the preceding one. This one is a bit heavier on the science details than the others, which some readers may find off-putting. But I thoroughly enjoyed it. If you like hard sci-fi, Andy Weir is fast becoming a modern master of the genre.
title: Weir just keeps getting better!

author: L. Lee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: To say that I loved this book is an understatement.  The characters are compelling, the story is heartrending, and the science is challenging on a level that only Andy Weir can accomplish.  As with The Martian, once I finished I immediately wanted to go back and start from the beginning and re-read the whole thing.  Enjoy!!
title: Absolutely BRILLIANT!!

author: Matthew Flower
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2021
review_content: I’ll start by saying that Weir’s “The Martian” is one of my favorite books. This book had so much of the same feel to it.  There’s a lot of richness in the situations the main character finds himself in. How he gets out of them makes this book a page turner.I don’t want to talk too much about the premise of the book, because I don’t want to ruin it. If you like space, adventure, and problem solving it’s probably going to be interesting for you.
title: I Loved It As Much As The Martian

author: McGnarman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: Obvious fan of Weir’s previous work I was excited for this release. Quickly, I hated having to put this book down and finished it in 8 days, a record for myself. Every chapter keeps you on your toes, the way the story unfolds is exciting and enlivening, and before you know it you’re attached to nearly every character. I will anxiously await another novel!
title: Another fantastic release

author: Kalin A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021
review_content: The book is a perfect summer read with need of serious editing.Fast paced, fun, interesting  grabs you from the very beginning and keeps you entertained until about 2/3rds of it. And then it kinda falls apart. How many turns and twists and sciency things can you cram in one place? It just gets too much and I don’t think the author had the right editor to tell him to stop. Same as the 2 previous books btw.Other than that, it is a good story and I would recommend it. Can’t wait for the movie
title: The book is a perfect summer read with need of serious editing

author: W. D. Ryder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review_content: Believable science without resorting to FTL.Fanastic character development.Brilliant ideas about aliens.Satisfying ending.Great prose which does not get in the way of the story.I've read SF for 50 years and is easily one of the best I have ever read. I love The Martian, enjoyed Artemis but this is next level.
title: It's a masterpiece!

author: G. Robert Grant
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed The Martian and Artemis but this book was insanely good.  I absolutely loved the plot and the characters.  The way things are revealed slowly throughout really adds to the plot’s impact.  I hope Andy Weir never stops writing and the books keep getting better because this one will be hard to top.
title: Outstanding book.  Best Weir yet

author: Rockabilly Reject
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: This is without a doubt the best Science Fiction book that I have read in many years. If you enjoyed "the Martian" this book is by the same author. This book gets my highest recommendation. Within a few pages, I care about a fictional character in a way that is unparalleled. Do yourself a favor and read this book.
title: The Best Science Fiction Book that I've read in years!

author: Tognazzini
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2021
review_content: I read lots of science fiction.  Trust me when I say this book is what it is all about.  This author has again explored the frontiers of our scientific understanding (science) and at the same time exposed his readers to human emotional experiences (fiction) that very few science fiction authors have been able to accomplish.  Through this author's writing, we are stimulated into thinking about catastrophic changes affecting our continued existence as a species, but also what we might be able to do during our short life times to survive those changes.
title: As usual, Andy Weir writes another masterpiece

author: tl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: I’m about one of the pickiest people when it comes to books if it doesn’t capture my attention quickly I’m just not gonna read it. Simple. This book is by far the best book I’ve read in a while it’s story is very articulate and it makes you feel like you’re a scientist by the end of it with all its calculations and problem solving. I recommend this book for just about anyone who liked the movie or book The Martian.
title: Amazing Book

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: This book echos a lot of the themes of the author's first book. A lone man, using science and ingenuity to fight against fate. The stakes are much bigger this time, though, and a new element is added to the mix. In the end, this was an exciting story from beginning to end and I enjoyed every minute of it.
title: A return of the science nerd hero

author: AlienMindProbe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: As an engineer, I really enjoyed The Martian because the heroes use STEM to save the day.  The beginning of Project Hail Mary was in the same mold and I was thoroughly enjoying it... until the appearance of the alien.  I won’t give away any more story details but I found myself rolling my eyes for the rest of the book.  It was like the book turned into a Steven Spielberg movie.  Reading the other reviews, it seems like most other people loved the book so I guess I am a contrarian.  The book was just a disappointment to me.
title: Too cutesy

author: Christine Kennedy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021

author: Jeff Gomske
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I consider The Martian my favorite fictional novel of the last 15-20 years. The movie was incredible in that they actually followed the book closer than 99% of other films based on books. It remains my favorite movie of the last 15 years or so as well. I don't know anyone (personally) that loves either of them as much as I do.With that said, I was REALLY looking forward to Artemis. It was good...but, it was certainly not in the same caliber as The Martian was (at least not for me). I enjoyed it a lot, however and appreciated how author Andy Weir chose to go in a completely different direction and not just rehash another similar story, which I am certain would have been great as well.As a result, I was cautious regarding Project Hail Mary. It sounded a little too close to The Martian, but yet, also different in that the circumstances simply could not be more opposite and the stakes so much higher. I'm trying to figure out the best way to summarize without giving too much away from this utterly compelling novel. As I read several reviews, I noticed a recurring theme: SCIENCE. Lots and LOTS of science. Holy cow, they were right. Many years ago I read Apollo 13 and Jim Lovell and his co-writer, try as they might, simply could not dumb down Orbital Mechanics anywhere near enough for me to have even a minor clue as to what they were attempting to say...I just skipped 90% of it and hoped that the sentences written afterwards, would help to make sense of what I had just skimmed over. I'm a lot of things, but a math wizard is definitely not one of them. Michael Crichton (Jurassic Park) had an amazing talent for dumbing-down the science of what he was trying to explain in ways that genuinely made sense (most of the time). Not everyone has this talent, and I would say Andy Weir falls squarely in between. He's certainly better than Jim Lovell, but not quite as good as Crichton. But then again, outside of a science textbook, I haven't really read anything with quite as MUCH science as Project Hail Mary. So maybe he's just as good, but he just puts more science into his books than Crichton, maybe that's it...? Either way, be prepared for a lot of astonishingly interesting science within the pages of this novel...and I DO mean a LOT. I don't say this to make you wary or steer you away...on the contrary, Andy Weir has a special talent for making hard science truly entertaining.The book opens with an absolutely amazing and frightening premise: an astronaut awakes from an induced coma to find the only other two people on board have died at some point along their journey...but it gets worse. He has no idea who he is, or why he's on the ship, and oh yeah, they look to be a long way from home. A really, REALLY long way from home. In fact, the sun he sees isn't actually OUR sun at all. He's managed to leave our solar system entirely. And he has no idea why.((Minor Spoilers)) The book goes through some clever flash-backs, which set the stage for why the mission happens, and slowly, carefully explains how they managed to get so far away from earth in such a short amount of time. Basically, earth's sun seems to be dying. At the rate of decay, we have maybe 19 years left before the gradual cooling has catastrophic consequences resulting in the death of billions (best guess). Why the sun is dimming is quite the conundrum in the first place. Turns out it really isn't dying, it's being killed by an outside source...which turns out to be easily the greatest find in history. It's alien life, and they are using the sun for food, essentially. It's alien life, but not intelligent life. But still, wow! ALIENS, right???After this monumental discovery, and some tremendous research done by the most improbable scientist, the investigation into what is happening and why and what to do about it expands exponentially to other nations in order to pool all the resources possible to hopefully save the sun, and by extension, the human race as well. They learn. A LOT. A plan is put together, and with the help of the newly discovered microscopic alien life, which can also double as a power source (along with a few other nifty surprises), they begin to create one last, Hail Mary that could very well be the last chance we might have to save earth. It's audacious. It's dangerous, and it is absolutely critical that it succeed.As our astronaut's memory slowly unravels, so does his identity: Ryland Grace. He's a teacher on earth. Just a science teacher. Not even a college professor. He's amazingly smart, though. But he's no astronaut...and certainly not one who would volunteer to go on a one-way mission to another solar system to "try" and save humanity. Yet here he is. Alone. light years from earth, trying to solve the biggest riddle in all of human history. Ryland accepts his situation, such as it is, with relative indifference (for the most part). It doesn't matter HOW he got here. He's here now and he may as well use that time to be as productive as possible, right? Along the way, he unravels even more information regarding the microscopic alien life which is slowly dimming our sun during some additional flashbacks. The aliens, dubbed, "Astrophage" are quite the galactic plague as it turns out. Stars all over the galaxy are also losing their light, all due to the little buggers. All that is, except one particular star named, Tau Ceti. Now why would that one star be unaffected by Astrophage, when every single star around it has been affected to some degree. The plan is to go there and figure it out and send the information back, hopefully in time to save the sun before the damage to earth is beyond repair.There is an incredible amount of stuff going on. The story switches from Tau Ceti to flashbacks of how the whole mission was planned and implemented (which is VERY entertaining, especially Director Stratt, who may actually be my favorite character in the entire novel). Weir is becoming quite adept at building tension, and abruptly switching the story from Tau Ceti back to earth and building more of the backstory then switching back to Tau Ceti. Keeping it all in check and most importantly, interesting all while mixing in a healthy dose of science, which I am to understand is pretty much all genuine, is quite the juggling act. I have long known science can be astronomically entertaining (see what I did there?) when done right...but unfortunately very few people in a position to teach science actually know the best way to create that interest in others. I can say without reservation, Andy Weir definitely knows how to do it...at least in written form.There is so much I want to say more regarding this truly phenomenal story, but I simply cannot without ruining a lot of the fun and surprises revealed along the way...and it is killing me to keep it locked in. Though I labeled a spoiler warning earlier, I don't think it gave away any more than what the author himself has revealed in interviews he has done regarding the book, and what you can glean from reading the summary here and just a couple other reviews. Tying all of that science together is truly astonishing to me. The creativity to put it into a novel that is remarkably exciting to read is nothing more than incredible talent. Kudo's to Andy Weir for not just hitting a home run, Project Hail Mary is a Grand Slam all the way. I truly did not want this story to end. By the way, I enjoyed the ending quite a bit. I don't know if everyone will. But it was fine for me. I think the ending screams "sequel" at some point too. A lot was left open-ended (IMO) and I wouldn't mind reading a follow-up to this. It doesn't HAVE to happen, but there are a lot of ways where the story could go if Andy chose to do it. Just sayin'.Just run out and buy this book.

author: Daniel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: According to a 2003 article on the NASA website, "NASA-funded scientists have recently learned that cloud-to-ground lightning frequently strikes the ground in two or more places ..." and that the third and fourth strokes of a lightning flash will follow the same path as the second stroke.  In other words, lightning DOES strike the same place twice.But you don't need to search the web for this information.  If you want proof that lightning strikes twice, just read Andy Weir's newest book, Project Hail Mary, and you'll see that Weir has created a giant sci-fi bestseller, in the same electric path as The Martian.Ryland Grace has a puzzle on his hands.  He wakes up without a clue as to where he is, but he seems to be alone except for a computer AI that was keeping him alive. Unfortunately it didn't seem to be doing the same for two others in his ... wherever he is ... as he notes the decayed corpses in their creches on the ... well, it's a ship.  A space ship. And bit by bit Grace puts the pieces of the puzzle together.An alien microbe has been discovered. Ryland Grace is brought on to the science team to learn more about the life form because Grace, currently a middle school science teacher, wrote papers about the notation that there does not need to be water to create life.  Only in a biozone such as Earth's would water be needed, but other building blocks could be used in other systems.The science community as a whole mocked Grace, which is why he left and went on to teach kids, but now, he may be the best suited to understand this new life form. And as he remembers more and more, he also remembers that this life form is feeding on the energy output of the sun, which is decreasing the energy that gets to Earth, which spells disaster - as in the end of all life as currently known - on Earth if something isn't done.Scientists discover that Sol isn't the only star that is losing its energy output - likely due to the alien consumption, but that there is one star, in the center of all the known stars losing their energy, that remains constant with its output.  In which case, the answer to the survival for Earth is likely found there, at Tau Ceti.The world's best scientific minds come together (by force and coercion) to create a ship that can get to Tau Ceti in twelve years (using the alien microbe as fuel) with shuttle pods to bring back answers to how to save the planet, but for the crew, it's a one-way trip.Knowing why he's there is only the first puzzle for Grace.  Now he has to figure out how to save Earth.  There's a very small window of time for him to discover the way to save the human race and get the answers sent back.  Take too long and the shuttles will return to a dead planet.This book is amazing.Author Andy Weir brings us back to the magic that made The Martian so successful - an abandoned scientist trying to survive.  But Ryland Grace's story is more complicated because he's not just trying to survive, but also help humanity survive.There's lots and lots of science - which is part of Weir's writing signature - and there's also a really wonderful story.It's hard for me to tell you just what I liked about this book because anything I write will be a spoiler and a huge part of the joy in this book is making the discoveries with Ryland Grace.Grace is our main character, but through the liberal use of flashbacks, we have a full cast of characters - at least one quite important to the story. Everyone is unique and individual which makes it easy to read, but just as with The Martian, where Mark Watney's personality carries the story, Ryland Grace here is the smart-mouth, sometimes funny, obsessed scientist infusing his personal tastes into his discoveries. He's also quite smart - which is good since he will need his intellect to save all of humanity.This is a page-turner. I did not want to put this book down. Neither did my 21 year old son who picked up my copy after I was well into it and finished it before I did. And days later he's still talking about how much he liked it and quoting sections of it to me at the dinner table.I hope Ballantine Books will do a very large print run because this is going to be huge seller and you definitely don't want to miss out on the biggest thing to come out in 2021.Looking for a good book? Project Hail Mary by Andy Weir is proof that lightning strikes twice as this has all the excitement and energy of Weir's debut novel, with a more complicated storyline that will hold the reader all the way to the end.

review_content: First and foremost, if you liked The Martian - in either book or movie form - you will almost definitely like this book.  The best way I can describe it is that Andy Weir watched the film adaptation of his own first book and thought "Wow! I should write a book like that!"As many other reviewers have mentioned, this book has a lot of the same building blocks that made The Martian so much fun: lone astronaut incredibly far from Earth, detailed scientific problem-solving, and light, cheesy humor.  It's a nice blend.  Weir also does a great job of writing the crisis moments as page-turners where the book is hard to put down.That being said, the book isn't perfect.  I would rank it a fairly distant second to The Martian but ahead of Artemis.  Without going into spoilers, the setting for the book overall feels significantly more contrived than in either of Weir's previous books.  It was fairly easy to imagine Mark Watney on Mars in 10-20 years, so everything in The Martian felt very realistic and grounded.  Here, not so much.  The main character in Project Hail Mary also feels generally less likeable and less human than Watney did.  There were chunks of the book where I genuinely did not care whether the mission succeeded - I just was not as invested as I was in Mark Watney getting home from Mars.All in all, this book is worth a read if you like Andy Weir's other work.  It's probably worth a read anyway - it's a very good book.  But it's not the masterpiece that a lot of other reviews are claiming.
title: A Decent, Fun Read

author: Renee LS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021
review_content: Three and 1/2 stars for some fun bits, but this is easily a YA novel with far too much MacGuiver-ing for my taste.
