title: Fun, but best for YA readership

author: Roger T. Cutler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: The core science, that of the power source, is explained in great detail and is grossly incorrect.  If you are going to use antimatter as a power source you have at least three challenges: 1)Where do you get the antimatter; 2)How do you store it; 3)How do you use it?  Two out of three are explained by obviously incorrect mechanisms and the third is pretty implausible. 1)Antineutrino/Neutrino production supposedly occurs via pair production in thermal proton collisions.  I suppose this channel is conceivable, but it would proceed via a vitual Z boson, which is a neutral particle about 90 times the mass of the proton that interacts only weakly.  "Weakly" is the key word here.  The crosssection for such an interaction would be fantastically tiny.  I don't know whether it would take the age of the universe to observe production of a singly such pair, but I suspect it would be something like that.  2)Storing the neutrinos is supposedly accomplished via a miraculous cell membrane opaque to neutrinos.  The miracle is how such a membrane would be evolved, since there is no substance in the known universe that would give the cell the slightest start in this direction. 3)This is the worst -- the neutrinos and antineutrinos supposedly annihilate into photons. I guess the author thought this was likely since charged antiparticles like positrons annihilate into photons.  This is because they are charged.  Neutral neutrinos do not couple at all to photons. Period. Full stop. I don't really know what a confined bunch of thermal energy neutrinos would do, but I think probably nothing since the only decays available via the weak coupling are into products far more massive than the available energies. I'm not positive about that, but one thing for sure -- they are not going to annihilate into photons.There were other lapses of scientific plausibility, such as a casual disregard for momentum conservation when the super-cells blast out photons, for some reason in only one direction, and then left passively on the plate to be scraped off by a mechanical arm. And a few other, but the particle physics impossibilities are by far the worst.As an adventure story it's reasonably well written, although it goes on far too long with one crisis after another being solved by combining human and alien technology. It gets to be a bit "Perils of Pauline" after a while.
title: Ridiculously Bad Science

author: E Mueller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: The English language doesn't contain the words to convey how much I love The Martian. When I recommend it, I (a SF/F fan) tell people it's probably the best SciFi book I've ever read.But Project Hail Mary is NOT The Martian. Don't get me wrong - it isn't bad. It's just.. fine. The bones are there - the story is good. I adore Rocky, but I found Ryland whiny and annoying. The only time I really appreciated his personality was when he was naming things - and he even whines about doing that. There's a lot of math and science, which isn't the least bit surprising, but it all fell flat to me in a way it didn't in The Martian. Maybe because I didn't like Ryland's personality, but it also didn't feel like most of the problems had the same immediacy as Whatney's.All in all, as I said, it was fine. I probably won't read it again and I'd only recommend it for people who liked the math and science from The Martian, not Whatney's irreverent humor.
title: Doesn't Live Up to The Martian

author: LocoCoyote
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2021
review_content: Up front, let me emphasize that I enjoyed the book and found it to be a fun read. It is not without problems though.The book feels like Mr Weir was trying too hard to replicate “The Martian”. So much so that it frequently feels forced. One of the things that drove me crazy was the constant presence of what I call “The Convenance Factor”. No matter what the situation or conditions, there is, conveniently, something that solves the problem. Alone on your ship with no memory of how you got there or how to run the ship? No problem…handy magic computers (or robot arms) that solve the problem. Don’t know something ? No problem! We sent a copy of everything ever written with you (including software games, etc). Need to fashion or manufacture things? No worries, we have a handy magic alien with unlimited skills who can make things almost instantly…<<<sigh>>> the convenience factor.But put that all aside, the ideas and science presented are intriguing although shallow. And to be fair, I did not see that ending coming.
title: A Fun Book, but…

author: Karen A. Wyle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: I might be rounding up a smidgen.Ryland Grace, like the protagonist of Weir's bestseller The Martian, is a resourceful fellow in an emergency -- though not so much of a natural engineer. How he overcomes that deficit is a delightful and very significant plot element. Other ways in which Grace differs from that astronaut are revealed fairly late in the story, and I won't spoil them.I originally thought the "amnesia from a coma" device might be unnecessary as an excuse for a dual timeline, but it turns out to serve another function as well. That aside, the dual timeline unfolds Grace's backstory at an agreeable pace.The nature of the crisis the Hail Mary is hoping to address, and the details that emerge about that crisis and a possible solution, are original and intriguing. And the suspense is considerable. The ending is a satisfying and surprising touch.
title: Resourceful protagonist, original and intriguing plot elements make this a very enjoyable read

author: Boomer Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: If you liked Andy Weir's freshman novel, "The Martian", you will love his most recent work.  I actually had to temper my reading pace so I could enjoy this book over a week rather than burn through it on one sitting.  This book is so much better than his sophomore novel "Artemis" and even out-does "The Martian. "  It will likely become an instant Sci Fi classic.  It is a very optimistic homage to humanity and to the importance of friendships made where you least expect to find them.  It's about admitting one's worst character flaws, overcoming one's primal fears, and doing what's right even at enormous personal cost.  Thrilling, exhausting, emotional and totally satisfying!Don't be put off by the reviews that say it requires the reader to have fundamental understandings of physics (particle, astro quantum, Newtonian and relativistic) chemistry, biology or astronomy (though that wouldn't hurt.)  Mr. Weir explains his protagonist's predicaments and solutions sufficiently to the "uneducated."  That said, if you do have a strong science background, you will appreciate even more the depth of the author's knowledge of science in general.  (Too bad the editor didn't ask him to write technical appendices, however.  It would make a great book for middle and high school English and Science teachers to co-teach! ) Get it, read it, enjoy it, then wait anxiously for the Ryan Gosling movie to get filmed!  I'm hoping it will be at least as good as "The Martian" because this book deserves it!
title: Believe the Five Star Reviews!

author: Doug Wagner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: I would not have believed that Andy would ever write anything better than The Martian.Artemis proved that he could consistently write good Science Fiction, and I was completely content with good...but, he hit one out of the park, with Project Hail Mary.This book is not just good...it is absolutely great!It is not only one of the best SF books I have ever read, it may be THE best that I have ever read!Science Fiction doesn't often bring a lot of humanity to the table. Characters are often mud puddle deep. But, our hero is as human as human gets. He's neither good nor bad, he's just unlucky enough to be the wrong guy at the right time. He gets to discover who he is at the same time we do...bit, by bit, in recovered memories.For readers who geeked out on The Martian, for all the science, there is enough plausible science in this to sate the appetite. You won't go away hungry!For readers who like a good human story, Ryland Grace may just make you proud to be human.
title: Far better than The Martian

author: D. P. Gmyrek
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2021
review_content: Got the book yesterday afternoon. Finished at 0330 today. Really enjoyed the story. The ending was a real twist. Glad I am cycling onto night shift, I needed to stay up all night and Hail Mary held my attention without fail. Highly recommend for SyFi fans.
title: A real page turner

author: Josefine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I'm not an expert when it comes to Science Fiction. In fact, I just started branching out into that genre, and Project Hail Mary was maybe my 10th scifi book. So, I don't have much to compare it to - just know that when you read my review.But, I loved this book! Andy Weir had me hooked from the first page and didn't let me go. And now I'm sitting here and want a sequel about what happened at the end...Andy Weird's humor is right up my alley. It's dark and sarcastic which made me laugh out loud multiple times.While there is quite a bit of scientific explanation in the book, I didn't get everything. I don't mind though. It makes it feel more real. Andy Weir explained a lot of the concepts. Some just went over my head and others, surprisingly, made sense. Surprisingly, because I was never great in science classes.The story itself is phenomenal. The main storyline and the flashbacks (or the moments in which Ryland gets his memory back) are well spaced out. None feel too overpowering. Every character was explained so well that I could easily imagine them and why they made the decisions they did. His entire journey is just... I'm not sure I have the right words... unbelievable. I couldn't put the book and just had to know how his story evolves. There were moments where I just sad there crying or where I was overly excited and happy because I could feel exactly what he was going through. And that ending.... man... soooo good!This is hands-down my favorite book of the year so far.
title: Not a science nerd, but this is my favorite book of the year.

author: mccccccccc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: This book was only "okay." I had higher expectations based on how much I liked The Martian.(Be careful, because, mild SPOILERS)PROS:  I liked Rocky's altruism and smarts, and learning about how alien life evolved.  Also, despite some drawbacks, I kept reading.  I had to know what happened, and I haven't been involved enough in a book in a long while that made me that interested in the characters.  So, kudos there.CONS:  The scenes on Earth, dealing with politics and how decisions get made, were completely unrealistic.  So were the parts about publishing/academia and how the main character (a middle school teacher) was suddenly promoted to be an astronaut -- just pure fantasy.  I also had issues with some of the humor - it seemed hokey/jokey, esp. when naming planets/natural phenomenon, or naming devices.But the main con was the over-over explanations of the science, which made me feel like I was reading a textbook at times or listening to someone really really dull over explain; this needed serious editing, because it really talked down to the reader, and, not only that, but much of the knowledge was broad, but not deep.So this was more like mind candy and not really a deep read.
title: Too much explaining

author: bradleyjmck
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2021
review_content: This is a triumph. As much as I, & everyone else I'm sure, loved The Martian this one stands right there with it. Its got the same hard sci-fi, but he makes it so fun & easy to understand. Its also got the same heart & drive of narrative; where every aspect, loss, goal, dream, & most of all accomplishments, that the character feels or experiences, you as the reader feel them too. Its just a wonderful ride through space. Andy really respects space & you definitely get that from his writing: its beautiful & incredibly dangerous.All that said, I cannot recommend the audio book highly enough. I've just recently gotten on the "read & listen" trend, & this is the first book where the narration is SO good I find myself just wanting to listen rather than read. And honestly, no spoilers, but some parts of this book are made to be listened to. That's all I'll say about it.Definitely read it, but listen to Ray Porter read it if you can.
title: Wow

author: Matt Pollicove
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I recently devoured Andy Weir's latest, "Project Hail Mary".I did not read Artemis, but I can tell you that this one had strong echoes of "The Martian" (TM) with pretty well flushed out science and thoughts about what could be.This is definitely more of a Fiction book than TM, but Weir did a great job extrapolating science and how things could work to support his plot.The story was excellent, and quite engaging. The humor and sarcasm is evident throughout and keeps things moving along. He uses a great combination of "current" action and flashbacks to tell a compelling story. A couple of things were a little predictable knowing Weir's general style, but then again, he never gives his protagonist and easy job.Oh yeah, by the way, it's gonna be a GREAT movie!
title: An Interstellar Epic!

author: Mal Warwick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: In Andy Weir’s blockbuster debut, The Martian, and in the 2015 film of the same name starring Matt Damon, astronaut Mark Watney digs himself out of one hole after another in a frantic effort to survive alone on Mars. Watney’s an engineer, and every problem presents itself as an engineering challenge. Now Weir has come out with a new novel, Project Hail Mary, and it’s much the same. A biologist-turned-middle-school-teacher named Ryland Grace is alone light-years from Earth on a suicide mission to save the human species. But his first job is to save himself. And the challenges he faces demand solutions that only clever engineering and a knowledge of science can solve.This book has a lot going for it. It’s suspenseful. Even hard to put town at times. Laugh-out-loud funny on occasion. Weir takes great care to base events on known physical, chemical, and biological properties. And the portrayal of alien life-forms is intriguing and seems plausible. But in the end it’s science fiction only an engineer could love. Again and again, for page after tedious page, Ryland Grace tackles engineering problems to address a succession of threats and emergencies that come out of the woodwork (as it were). Grace—or, rather, Andy Weir—is devilishly clever, but it gets old fast.Here’s what happensRyland Grace is happily enjoying the adulation of his middle-school science students. Years earlier, a paper he had written as a rising young biologist challenged the accepted wisdom that all life requires water. The reaction among exobiologists was fast and furious, and Grace was driven from his research position at a university. Now, that same paper has forced him back into the public eye. A microscopic alien life-form called “Astrophage” is gobbling up the sun’s energy, and Grace has come to the attention of the extraordinary woman leading the international to save humanity from it. That effort is a Moon Shot to the power of ten or a hundred, and Eva Stratt commands all the Earth’s resources to address the threat. Including Ryland Grace, whether he likes it or not.In case you haven’t guessed, Andy Weir is a lot stronger on science and engineering than he is on international politics. The friendly global effort he posits is preposterous. It’s inconceivable to me that an existential threat, no matter how imminent, would induce the Americans, the Chinese, and the Russians to band together in a united effort engaging all their military and economic resources. Not going to happen.Not to belabor the tale, Grace assists Stratt in a breakneck campaign to construct an interstellar spaceship and train the crew of three selected to take it to the Tau Ceti system. There, Earth scientists have concluded, lies the origin of the Astrophage. Then a whole sequence of things go wrong, and Grace himself ends up on the starship Hail Mary—alone. Because his two crewmates have died en route. And to make matters worse, he wakes from a coma with amnesia. It takes him a long, long time to figure out where he is and what happened to take him there. The upshot is, Ryland Grace is “all that stands between humanity and extinction.” And then the really big surprises start coming. . .About the authorComputer programmer Andy Weir (1972-) self-published The Martian in 2011 and created such a stir that Crown Publishing Group picked it up and turned it into a bestseller. The book is often cited as one of the best science fiction novels of recent years. He grew up in Milpitas, California, and attended (but did not graduate from) the University of California, San Diego. He has written four novels and a slew of short stories, comics, graphic novels, and other materials.
title: Devilishly clever, but it gets old fast

author: TheBookRecluseReview
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: Project Hail MaryBy. Andy WeirP. 496Format: eArcRating: ***************************I received an e-arc from @Netgalley in exchange for an honest review. All opinions are my own. Then I bought the book.**********************Andy Weir took the science fiction world by storm with his release of The Martian. It was gritty hard science fiction. His second novel, Artemis, was not quite as revered. Although I personally loved it, it had a lot of similarities as The Martian. The main character just seemed to be a gender bent version of Mark.Project Hail Mary is different, and is my favorite Andy Weir book to date. Firstly, I must say there is not a single swear word in the entire book. I wouldn’t go so far as to say it was disappointing, but it was an obvious choice.The first part of the novel may be a bit slow. You are disjointed and have no idea what is going on, because the main character, Ryland, is disjointed and has no idea of what is going on. He has lost his memory and he seems to be alone in space.The novel is a combination of real time events as well as memory flash backs. It makes for a very thrilling narrative. Then pops in my favorite character ever of any book - Rocky. I won’t tell you much about him because it would spoil everything. But I love him. I will buy action figures of him. . . When someone decides to make them.If you love science fiction at all then read this book.
title: Project Hail Mary by Andy Weir

author: Cynthia Ross
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: (Updated below.)I'm halfway through and the story is riveting. I must say, that although it was fascinating to "witness" how Ryland's memories slowly returned, Weir's story became supercharged at the end of Chapter 6 when Ryland encounters--oops, that's telling! The main reason I'm writing this now is because I know there were some readers turned off by excessive cursing in The Martian as well as Artemis. Weir must have decided that his legacy may well be in the classroom (kind of like Ender's Game) and has toned it down. I think regardless of his reasons, it is an excellent choice. I think I've run into two F words at 50% in. They're not completely gratuitous, but classroom editions could delete them easily. So if you dislike swearing, I think you can feel pretty safe reading this novel, and you'll be really glad you did.Edited 5/12 - Just finished. I took my time with this. Yes, other reviewers said the math and science details made them lose interest. I kept going because the main characters were so sympathetic and fun. I shed tears several times during the tale. It was so very life-affirming. Reading this novel has enhanced my life. I know I'll be reading it again. More of this, Andy! Maybe a sequel?!
title: Very little cursing! That is a surprise! This novel may well become a classic of SF

author: B Apfel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: But if you never read The Martian, you might love this book!  Look, no disrespect intended when I say that Andy Weir may be the sci-fi Dan Brown.  If you have a winning formula, why change the recipe?Another super smart creative protagonist Mark Watneys his way through harrowing situations, screwing up enough to seem almost fallible.  Lots of laughs and suspense and fun supporting characters that all seemingly share the same great intentions and senses of humor.I really enjoyed the book.  Rocky and Stratt were lovable characters.  The science and math thoroughly schooled me.  I was not expecting some of the directions the story took early on.  But the ultimate outcome was never really in doubt, and how many times do we have to wonder “what now”?  Another problem that will be ingeniously solved only to lead to another and another.  It’s like a video game with escalating levels of challenges.In short, well-written, fun science, but not earth-shattering like The Three Body Problem series.  Better than Artemis, but more of a rehash than a recapturing of his stellar debut.
title: If you loved The Martian, you’ll like Hail Mary

review_content: I wanted to love it.  The Martian is still on my top ten list of all time great books.  This book, this story is frankly terrible.  Adding math to a story line that is laughable does zero to reclaim it's value.  I hope the author is not reading this review because I don't want to hurt his feelings -  if he really thought this was ready for prime time. author: Margaret A. Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I totally second the Washington Post's blurb:  "If you loved The Martian, you’ll go crazy for Weir’s latest."Project Hail Mary is the true sequel to The Martian in that the protagonist uses SCIENCE (as Bill Nye would say) to solve his problems.He's not a trained astronaut.  In this case, he's something better – a middle school science teacher!  With years of living and breathing science trying to impart said science to his students.As a retired reference librarian myself, I can appreciate his broad knowledge of basic science. Plus, he had plenty of informative charts & posters in his classroom filled with useful basic science facts. (And access to Wikipedia!)Highly recommended for page-turning action and plenty of both spunk & heart!  You won't be able to put this book down!
title: True sequel to The Martian, if you love a plucky guy & SCIENCE!

author: R. Ault
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: I'll avoid spoilers here, as much as possible.  The premise of the book is "oh, noes, we are all DOOMED unless we can do a desperate long-shot Thing to Save Us All", which never stands the scrutiny of "yeah, and how often does that happen", really, but works well enough if the author is sufficiently skillful.  Andy does a decent if not entirely stellar job with it.  So if you can set that aside, then this develops into a well-fleshed-out tale of The Clever Duo Meshes Well To Solve Their Problems, even if it is a bit handwavy in places.  (But really, that's another Great Tradition Of The SF Genre, so let's just politely tiptoe past and hope the elephant doesn't notice the peanuts in our backpacks.)Bottom line?  Worth the weekend that most will need, in my opinion.  Have fun.
title: A good read, if a bit heavy on the old trope of "What these people need is an Earther."

author: Jeannie Mancini
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: In the language of America's Got Talent..."It's a YES from me!" I just turned the last page feeling very satisfied that Andy Weir did it again. It's different..a very unique story for sure. The only word I can use to describe this novel is..heartwarming. Do I think it's as good as The Martian? Yes, but in a different way. The Martian was an action packed edge-of-your-seat thrillride. Project Hail Mary has some of that, but it is geared toward the strength, determination, and the special bond of friendship between two unlikely heroes all alone in space. One human, one alien, both desperately trying to save their home worlds against a deadly source that is devouring the sun. You will laugh, you will cry, and you will cheer them on. And I promise..you will love the end.😉
title: Andy Weir is back and kicking success!

author: CB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: I enjoyed the story.  The author developed a plot point that simultaneously solved a critical problem with interstellar travel.  Very clever.  The second half of the book became a bit too much far-fetched for my liking though.  Having our main character accidentally become a sole traveler but also run into another species in the same situation?  hmmm.  And then, to describe the reason for the second species being in that situation as because they did no know about radiation.  Ok... one in a billion now becomes one in a trillion. Our hero has his moment denied.  A good story but don't overthink it.
title: Enjoyable Science Fiction

author: Dr. Alan Cohn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: A truly amazing masterpiece of speculative fiction, by the author of  “The Martian” (and follow-up movie). To my mind, this ranks with some of the best including Arthur C. Clarke’s“Childhood’s End”. It is a rarity to find a thinker and writer who can make you conceive that the science and universe he posits has a validity. title: A Masterwork not to be missed.

author: MTH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
review_content: It has to be said. . .if you liked the Martian, you'll love Project Hail Mary.The MAIN structure of the book is that a problem arises and the main character (Ryland Grace) must "science up" a solution, which he does over and over again. And if the book was just that, it would be excellent. It's well paced. The central problem is introduced quickly. The "out of the frying pan into the fire" moments are not just brought up and tossed-away but usually lead to an understanding or technique that is revisited later. It is a page-turner. Each separate incident is intriguing while constantly driving the main story forward.But (here come the spoilers)The stakes are large here. Not just the survival of the Grace, but the survival of the human race. He must travel to a distant star to find the reason that that star is not being eaten alive by a single-celled organism that is eating the earth.What differentiates this book from The Martian is the relationship that develops between Grace and Rocky. . .a hard-shelled -- arthropod (?) -- from an alien world who is at the distant star making an effort to solve the same problem for ITS home world.There is a sequence (again, a similarity to the Martian) where they must learn to communicate. Even though Rocky is not anthropomorphic, you develop a sense of its personality and the norms of its race.We learn that Rocky's entire crew has died during the journey to the star, and furthermore that one of the practices of its race is to watch each other sleep. When Rocky asks Grace to watch it sleep, it's emotional and heartbreaking and the entire relationship between the two characters grows and strengthens from there.Watching their friendship develop while their scientific skill sets mesh together to solve problem gives the book a weight that the Martian just didn't have and I don't think many sci-fi authors are capable of pulling off.  That this came from an author who so far has shown more willingness to write about chemical reactions than interpersonal interactions is especially enheartening.The last chapter was just. So. Perfect. Right down the last paragraph.Just so well done. One of my favorite books I've read in so long.
title: Superb. Flavors of the Martian but so much better. Review contains spoilers.

author: V. A. Stevens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
review_content: Loved this book.  I usually borrow books from our local library or use Prime Reading .  I also haunt thrift stores and  our used book stores.  I was really looking forward to reading Andy Weir's new book and after reading the reviews I just could not wait and I  purchased it.  Yes, I paid retail for this book!  And I'm glad I did not wait for my library hold to become available.Ryland Grace is a surprising character.  We learn more about him as he is remembering his past.  I thought his amnesia was going to be a gimmick, but Andy Weir skillfully uses it to measure out information about Ryland Grace.  Discovering what happened and why he is on this mission along side following his progress on the Hail Mary kept me reading and ignoring everything else.  Eeverytime my husband came over to talk to me I told him I was reading Andy Weir's new book and the sooner I finished, the sooner he could read it.Without giving away the unexpected happenings in the book, it is hard to explain how much fun it is when  just as I think I have the next bit figured out, boom, wow, thing explode in new directions.  So many times in other books the author drops too many or to obvious hints and I'm not surprised at what happens.  Andy Weir keeps veering around in ways I did not see coming.I love science fiction, but so much gets lumped in with fantasy that finding hard science novels is hard.  I enjoyed the science in Project Hail Mary and the way that it is explained so I can follow along without getting bogged down and having to reread the explanations.  It is fun be reminded of how much science I used to know without having to use Bing to find answers.Yeah, spend the money and head off on an adventure you'll never forget.  Thank you, Andy Weir!
title: WOW!  I had so  much fun reading this book!

author: Sharon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: Wow! I loved the Martian and Artemis, But Project Hail Mary blew them away.Something is causing the sun to dim and that is causing major climate change on earth. If not fixed earth will become extinct in a couple of decades. Governments all over the world work together to come up with a plan. And that plan is Project Hail Mary, which will send 3 astronauts into space to find out how to stop the sun from dimming. This trip for the astronauts is basically a suicide mission as they will not be able to return to earth.One of the astronauts is actually science teacher Ryland Grace and it is his POV that the story is told. When the story opens Ryland has just awoken from suspended animation but has no memory of where he is or why. His 2 crew mates have unfortunately died so he is all alone. As he is checking out the ship his memory gradually comes back and he remembers that he is supposed to be saving earth and that he is going to die. I loved Ryland. Even though he knows he is going to die he was was funny and had me chucking a lot.The book is told in 2 timelines. Present time when he is on his mission to save earth and also in the past via memories and from those we learn how Project Hail Mary came to be as well as how Ryland a science teacher ended up on the mission.I cannot say anything else because best to go into this book unknown. But aside from Ryland there was another character that I loved. And the book takes a twist that I did not see coming but I Loved!!There was a lot of science stuff that I didn’t understand but in no way did that take anything away from this book. I have been so excited to read this book and now that I am done I want to read it again. I loved it that much.
title: Wow! I loved the Martian and Artemis, But Project Hail Mary blew them away.

author: Scott E. High
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: If you enjoyed either the book "The Martian" or the resulting movie, then don't miss a chance to pick up "Project Hail Mary".  This is a well-written story about a quest to save Earth as well as a planet in a neighboring galaxy, both of which are endangered by the same threat.  Author Andy Weir has come up with a plausible scenario that only a fertile and imaginative mind could conjur without sounding ridiculous.His newest novel is crammed with science and ingenuity, taking the reader on an intestellar journey that could easily have been over written and turned into a pure math and science tome.  But Mr. Weir avoids this while still periodically challenging your memories of science and math probably left far behind in your high school years.  And that is a good thing because this could have ended up being a very dry novel.The author extolls the virtue of hard work and the ethical tests of 'never giving up'.  He does so in a good way, adding subtle humor and sarcasm as needed to lighten the mood during unexpected (and serious) challenges, and all the while allowing his characters to learn more about themselves and their true capabilities.  The old addage of "what man can think of man can create" comes to play here.This is the story of the human spirit rising to the challenge facing all of mankind by using imperfect people to  conquer devestating situations.  It is a true story of hope against all odds.  And it's well worth your reading.
title: No Sex, Violence Or Rock & Roll

author: SD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: I'm making a note here, huge success! It's hard to overstate my satisfaction. Andy Weir science, he wrote what he did, because he can. For the good of all of us, at least the ones who can read. And he'll keep on writing because there's science to do, I can't wait for the next novel, but this one is still new, so the reading gets done, I hope he writes another one, because this guy's the best author alive! I loved this book and he's the best author alive, lost sleep over it because he's the best author alive, can't wait to read the next book from the best author alive, still alive, still alive!  Seriously, this is a good book, perhaps better than the Martian. You should buy it. And if you didn't get the reference above go play Portal till you win.
title: This is a Triumph!

author: Aspiring Author
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: I expected this to be a “hard” science fiction story and it was. The creativity in this story is exceptional. It is hard to find new ideas in SF that don’t come across as re-dos of old ideas. A lot of science-related research was clearly done in the development of the story. I am a fan of hard science fiction and this is a prime example of it. Bravo!!From a literary standpoint, this is a dual-timeline novel. The main story line forms one timeline, with the secondary timeline consisting mostly of backstory. Further, the first-person protagonist is the main character in both timelines. A challenge with this approach is that the author builds up suspense in the main timeline and then pulls us over to the secondary timeline where there is often little or no suspense. The suspense vanishes, only to return later on. A possible solution to this would have been to suppress details in the secondary timeline. This would have shortened the book, which I think would be a good idea. I read the Kindle version and, when I thought it a bit long, I checked the length of the hardcopy book: 496 pages. In my opinion at least 100 pages could be removed from the hardcopy. In general, detail is included in a novel to make it appear more believable. Detail in the backstory could have been brushed over.There is a hint of the “Hero’s Journey” storyline in this story. It has a twist that didn’t set well with me. I can’t say more without saying too much.
title: Imaginative and Creative

author: Charles Boyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: Andy Weir is a good writer, and one smart enough to not write the same book twice. Project Hail Mary is not The Martian Redux, nor is it another telling of Artemis. It starts with a mystery that wrapped inside another mystery, and then it becomes a story of friendship and courage that takes an unexpected turn.The Sun's output has mysteriously diminished, threatening Earth's ecosphere as a whole. In Michael Crichton-like fashion, our hero comes to the problem because of some tangentially related research he'd done in the past, research that made him a pariah who escapes to teaching middle-school science. It's something he's quite good at, and it makes him an unlikely hero in our save-the-world story. He's still his own man, and throughout his saga, he stays true to himself.  There's no magical transition from ordinary man to superhero, and that makes him all the more realistic.Some might quibble with the plot-science used in the book, but at the same time, it is a novel that doesn't need to beg for suspension of disbelief. The devices Weir uses are believable enough, and if he got this or that a little wrong, so what -- it's not glaring enough to be irritating.Bottom line, as the onion of a story gets peeled, there are times it will make you want to cry for the characters, make you cheer for them and make you want them to succeed.  All in all, you'll be satisfied.
title: Believable, And Compelling

author: DHMorrell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: I thought Weir was a fabulous writer with his first two novels, but boy he's getting even better.  It's not just the hard sci-fi, he's a brilliant writer of characters, and timing of the plot.  Planning the science of the story and writing it brilliantly are two different hemispheres of the brain.  A big 'ol bump-of-my-fist, Mr. Weir.
title: Happy, happy, happy

author: James Tepper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: Whew! What a ride! I didn’t think Weir could possibly top THE MARTIAN but PROJECT HAIL MARY is at least as good and maybe better. It’s got a great plot that starts out seeming somewhat familiar (i.e., last ditch attempt by a united Earth to quickly send up an experimental interstellar space ship to try to fix a “the end of the world as we know it” scenario) but rapidly diverges into something totally original.  The novel employs a time-shifting strategy, with one set of scenes from the past chronicling the lead-up to the launch and the alternates taking place in the “present”, perhaps several decades from now.As with the MARTIAN, there are plenty of twists and turns, and unexpected reveals from start to finish. One of these quite unexpectedly adds a new layer to the plot reminiscent of a “buddy road trip movie”.  The writing is excellent.  The prose is filled with great science including some new physics and biology, and more than a bit of intentional humor. In parts it gets a little “mathy” (but it’s Weir after all) but the nearly 500 page novel flies by in no time.  I usually say more about aspects of the plot but the Amazon page blurbs themselves almost risk spoilers and this novel deserves to be read completely unspoiled.Just Read it.Very highly recommended!!JM Tepper
title: An absolute masterpiece - no spoilers review

author: T. Whitman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Just ok.If you like lengthy descriptions of scientific process, then you’ll enjoy this book. That is 95% of it.Sadly, I found it tedious, and the characters shallow.Loved the Martian, this one, not so much.
title: Not my fav

author: Anne Somewhere
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: Best book I have read in a very long time. Perhaps, like me, you studied the sciences in college, but went on to a career in a different field. If you're looking for a book to remind you why you studied science in the first place, well, here it is...You will spend an afternoon reading it, and another week (or the rest of the year) tracking down the answers to the questions you jotted down. You'll put your old poster of the periodic table back up on the wall in your home office. Then you'll order a microscope, and a telescope, and several sets of high school chemistry experiments online, resubscribe to the science journals, find the best new 'space' blogs, and start planning trips to Palomar, Kennedy Space Center, CERN and the many other places you abandoned in favor of a job behind a different desk, twenty years ago.Trust me when I say this book will change your trajectory.
title: Inspiring

author: Klapaucjusz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2021
review_content: Who said that apocalyptic stories have to be either gloomy or silly?This book is truly unique. It is so good that I could not resist adding my 5 stars review to over 8K of other enthusiastic reviews.This story has so many original (and sometimes quite serious and complicated) ideas that kept amazing me !And at the same time it made me laugh out loud on several occasions.Without giving  spoilers I can just say that the most of both were about the contacts of humans with extraterrestrial life.The main protagonist’s narration was priceless. It reminded me of narrator in “Martian”. I just loved his unbeaten spirit, practical way of thinking and self deprecating humor.But if “Martian:” was 5 stars and “Artemis” was 4 stars ( for me) “Project Hail Mary” is 6 stars.I did not check or analyzed the plausibility of all the technological and scientific facts; after all it is a sci-fi and not a textbook. I just enjoyed the smoothly flowing story (especially parts about extraterrestrial life).
title: Original ideas and plenty of humor !

author: Petri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: The hype doesn't live up to the reading experience.  The first pages were interesting, but from then on the plot advances from one emergency to another as if the author didn't believe in the strength of the main story but chose to move it forward though constant action to keep the reader entertained.  It gets old very quickly, just like too much action in a movie does for many a viewer.The greatest weakness was the implausibility of the interaction between the protagonist and the secondary main character.  They come from completely different backgrounds but soon communicate with nuance.  Maudlin sentimentality and juvenile humour are added to the interaction so that the movie wouldn't be just all science.However, some of the science was interesting and some plot twists were unpredictable, even though you were fairly certain the protagonist and the secondary main character were going to survive, as they do in Hollywood movies, which the novel will be turned into.  The movie will probably make lots of money and keep the average viewer entertained through spectacular special effects and continuous action.  It's a pity people can't make sci-fi masterpieces like 2001: A Space Odyssey anymore.
title: Disappointing

author: Rob Archer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: "Project Hail Mary" is fantastic! Andy Weir's first novel, The Martian, was picked up nearly immediately as a major motion picture with Matt Damon and turned into a big hit. This computer programmer's third novel, his best yet, continues to prove that this was no fluke.The glorious thing about Project Hail Mary is not just that the science in the science fiction is so good, or that the fiction in the science fiction is so good, but the HUMANITY underlying it all. A marvelous novel in ANY genre.I understand this one's been picked up for a movie, too. If the producers are faithful to the story, there's going to be a lot of, er, dust in my eyes by the end. It emotionally socked me pretty hard in the last few pages.
title: Another big win for a consistent winner

author: Kwoeltje
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2021
review_content: More "competence porn" for fans of The Martian. Ryland Grace is a more complicated character in many ways than Mark Watney, which is a good touch. Some reviews complain about the steady stream of problems - but that's exactly what you'd get on this mission. There are a several surprise twists that are more about the characters than "yet another problem to solve", which also added depth to this book. I read a review in a major newspaper this morning that complained about the lack of checklists. While maybe a little valid, the majority of the issues that arise couldn't have been solved with "a checklist and common sense" - there's no way the appropriate checklist would have already been developed. And we know that Grace does do testing, so it's implied that he has procedures for that (and the testing seems rigorous, it just wasn't made explicit). And there's no lack of common sense. Overall as good a book as I was expecting.
title: Technical Sci Fi (no spoilers)

author: Daniel B. Lyle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: "The Martian" was an intensely believable near-future adventure almost entirely based on real technology.  "Artemis" was a step up, detailing a fascinating moon society and moon-related Earth culture.  Here, Andy Weir takes us to truly alien technology and never before imagined alien life.  It's a real tour tour de force.  As a Ph.D. biologist, I was blown away.  Of course there are elements of pure fiction, which may or not ever happen or even be possible.  But granting the necessary suspension of disbelief in places, this was a work of pure SF genius.  Bravo!
title: Genius level hard-SF imagination

author: Spark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: Let me start by saying I did enjoy the book but if I’m being honest it fell far short of The Martian. In fact, it felt like “Mark Watney goes to the stars” given the similarities in the main character’s personality. The basic premise was interesting and Weir starts out with well thought out speculative science but it became increasingly hard to suspend my disbelief as the book went on. SPOILERS: The idea that a single human could figure out an alien language enough to be cracking jokes with them in a matter of weeks is ridiculous. Using math and science as a starting point makes sense, but it’s a mighty big jump to be explaining sarcasm.Overall, it was a good read but it felt a little lazy and I was really hoping for better.
title: Cute but...

author: Storyteller7
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: Junior high school teacher Ryland Grace wakes up on a small spaceship with amnesia, unsure of why he’s there, what he’s meant to do or even what his name is. His returning memory recalls a mission sparked by the discovery of alien life near the sun which is draining Earth's atmosphere of heat and will lead to an extinction event within 30 years. Grace must survive long enough to find a way to save the world using only his mind and the resources aboard his spaceship. Weir’s questioning, funny, wooden voice carries this book from the very first page. He is the perfect embodiment for a cosmic mystery that plays out with the same attention to detail—and poignant philosophical questions about the nature of self-discovery and ingenuity—found in Weir’s "The Martian", while Rocky and the entire Eridanian species are the best SF aliens since Larry Niven's Moties.
title: An intense space puzzle for science nerds, as well as a brilliant novel of alien contact.

author: Kate
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: I've read all his books and each book is better than the one before.  So much science it boggles the mind -- with every book I understand more and more about science, biology, biomes, space travel, etc., etc., etc... While there is a lot of science in this book, it's delivered in such a way it's understandable.  Don't get me wrong, some of the science went right over my head 🤔🤔  but most of it answered science questions that have long confused me.  The characters are well developed and I still find it hard to believe I fell in love with BOTH main characters!!  lol -- You'll understand what I mean after you read the book!  Enjoy!  It's some excellent writing!
title: Outstanding -- Again....

author: Kevin Tinto
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: Weir comes back to form with Hail Mary, doing what he does best: speculative hard science, with a solo lead who isn't too smart to cut himself down to size, usually with a humorous side note or observation. The speculative science is creative on the 'WOW!' scale and always has some basis in real-world physics.Given Weir's known attention to detail on known science, the plot twists are unexpected and a joy to discover. This is The Martian with the imagination chip in the author's head switched to the full 'on' position.
title: Back to what he does better than anyone else...

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: Andy Weir delivers another riveting science fiction narrative with rather more intense stakes than his previous works with the fate of humanity on the line in his latest offering. One of the draws the author brings to his stories is their scientific believability. The author takes more scientific liberties this time around with miracle materials that shouldn't exist and improbable interstellar microbes that have features only present in earth life. However these do not detract from the compelling narrative playing out on the pages. The author has previously demonstrated willingness to bend scientific fact for storytelling and I wholeheartedly agree as I would much rather read a compelling story with some scientific inaccuracies rather than a boring one that was completely correct scientifically.5/5 stars
title: Compelling and near believable narrative

author: Richard Albanese
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: Weir once again shows his scientific prowess in this tale of an interstellar voyage to save humanity. He takes great pains to make sure his science is correct. So much so, that I won't nitpick the small things (possible spoiler alert), such as the unimpeded acoustic transmission properties of solid xenonite and the impact to sound waves in high pressure ammonia atmospheres transitioning to normal pressure human atmospheres; nor how a blind race of beings who sense by sonar would ever think to 'look' to the stars and navigate in interstellar space.Regardless of these minor details, the story drew me in and I could not put the book down. I even got a little choked up at a certain point near the end when 2 friends had to say goodbye forever.A must read for Weir fans and all SciFi'ers out there!
title: Weir Does It Again!

author: Gordon S. Savage
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2021
review_content: WOW! Terrific book. Andy put together a plausible account of first contact that completely obliterated the stereotype and tense enough to make it hard to put down. I don't know how accurate his numbers and descriptions were, but they were consistent throughout and worked to keep the story moving. I loved the ending.
title: Technical Masterpiece

author: Karen B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review_content: As a person of wide-ranging interests—languages (no, not linguistics, languages, I used to be an opera singer & love learning to speak languages other than my native English—psychology, physics, biology, chemistry), this book was so much fun.  As in The Martian, a lot of great problem solving via science and maths.But over time, the reader comes to feel they know these characters, and what a pleasure it is to spend time with them!  There is a real intimacy and camaraderie that develops between the astronaut scientist and the alien he encounters.I don’t want to give away the story, so I won’t get specific.  But for any fans of hard sci-fi, this is a “must read.”Kudos to Andy Weir.  Another masterpiece!  I loved every moment of this book.  More, please!
title: The Martian was great.  This is greater.

author: Tod with 1 D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: It's been a few years since I read The Martian, my very first e-book, and I recently heard about Hail Mary.This book is very science/engineering intensive, which made it that much better as a novel. Too many stories have folks jumping into a spaceship and take a jaunt across the galaxy in a few hours, just like we take drives around the country, but this story goes into enough detail to make it realistic.Along with the technical aspects, this author wrote some pretty moving emotional passages.My only complaint is too many "gosh darn it," expresions, considering the number of "damns" and other saltier expressions our hero utters.Altogether, a well-rounded book by an author who can spin a great yarn.  Thank you, Andy Weir!
title: excellent sci-fi thriller

author: Weagle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2021
review_content: Well that was fun! For those who enjoyed Weir’s outstanding The Martian, his new novel is laced with the same wit and grounded in legitimate math and science. It’s a little more “out there” book, both literally and figuratively as it involves interstellar travel and extraterrestrial life. Alternating flashbacks provide an interesting narrative as protagonist Ryland Grace’s memory returns and he slowly begins to understand his Earth-saving mission and what needs to be accomplished. I ended up adoring Grace’s newfound companion and their friendship strikes some sweet notes amidst looming catastrophe. And now the phrase “You sleep. I watch.” has entered my lexicon as a sincere expression of caring about another - even if they don’t know what you’re talking about.
title: You sleep. I watch.

author: LSK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: I loved the Martian. This one may be even better. I was so anxious to find out what happened, I kept reading, hour after hour, glad I had a couple days off to fully enjoy this story. Quite possibly the best "human meets alien" book written so far. I teared up several times when emotions got the best of me. Andy Weir may be tempted one day to NOT write stories set in space, but I can't wait to see what he comes up with next, so I hope he keeps giving us excellent science fiction.
title: Fabulous!

author: D. Beatty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: There were multiple times in this story when I had to suspend my disbelief, but I really enjoyed this story.  The first chapter grabbed me right away and my interest was maintained throughout enough to finish it one day.  The stuff happening on Earth wasn't as compelling to me as what was happening in space.  But what was happening in space is so interesting it would be hard to beat.I first came across Andy Weir when The Martian became a hit on Amazon.  I was taken in by the concept of the science crowd-sourcing he had done to put the story together in a realistic way.  But what makes his writing even more compelling is his touch of humor throughout.  I didn't find myself engaged in his second book, but this one has me excited again.
title: Very enjoyable read

author: N. Mungan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: First, a disclaimer: I don’t usually read current science fiction, preferring literary or historical fiction. However, readers’ reviews of this book were so enthusiastic and I really enjoyed the movie The Martian, so I started reading the sample and it quickly captured and held my interest. The book is a real page turner and I finished it in record time for me. It is just as much a novel of suspense as it is of science fiction. The work is very imaginative and it really puts the “science” in science fiction. The first person narrator faces one problem after another but overcomes all of them with human ingenuity, similar to the plot of The Martian. Thus the book is an optimistic paen to the saving power of reason. But, without being preachy, intrusive or contrived, the author also touches on how self sacrifice is necessary for the survival of our species, any species ... indeed, that evolution itself begets altruism. So why not 5 stars? Well this is not Asimov, Bradbury or Heinlein. It is light easy reading and more like a great burger than a fine steak. The dialogue is often fairly stilted. The narrator’s internal dialogues ( thoughts) often read like an over-excited teen-ager uttering gosh golly gee whiz hackneyed phrases. That can be endearing, but it can also be schlocky. Most of the characters are one-dimensional stereotypes — the tough as nails female leader, the vodka swilling Russian, and so on. Those passages are real eye-rollers. But overall, I would still really recommend the book for all the positive reasons I lead with. Great as a vacation or before bed read! Well worth your time!
title: What a trip!

author: RTM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2021
review_content: Sci-fi fans will certainly get their money's worth from Andy Weir's new book.  First, humans face a dire threat from an alien life form (probably not what you think).  Then, the brightest minds invent a means of interstellar travel to deal with the threat.  Finally, Weir creates an unlikely hero who is an incredibly smart and brave high school science teacher.  Our hero finds himself marooned on the spaceship designed to save humanity, and has to solve a seemingly endless series of difficult problems to survive.  If this sounds familiar to readers of "The Martian," one of Weir's previous books, this time around the author adds some surprising plot twists.  All of this is wild and crazy, but I still found it entertaining.
title: A Wild and Entertaining Ride

author: OC Artist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: An excellent entertaining book! An adventurous emotional roller coaster, like his first book “The Martian”. I definitely recommend this Sci-Fi adventure to all who wonder what a Middle School Science teacher (with an awesome sense of humor) is doing out in space, to help save the world and the Universe, with a surprising new friend! “Yes, yes, yes!”  Please, do not become too critical of the science or the explanations, Ryland Grace is a Scientist, who decided to become an educator and discovered he was happier teaching children, until one of his scientific papers reaches notice. His point of view is that of an Educator translating everything to kids... which makes the pacing and events fun and feels down to earth!
title: A Science Teacher in Space!!! What next?! Read and See! You won’t regret it!

author: BeeCee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2021
review_content: There's little praiseworthy of this great science fiction story that hasn't already been said by other reviewers. So, all I want to say is that it's as good as, if not better than 'The Martian'. While I acknowledge that much of the science is "real science," which I just accepted as such, but some of the ideas presented really made me look differently at things, such as the gift of sight, that we accept as normal about ourselves. The science doesn't get in the way of a good story and the humor in the first-person narration made the reading experience even more fun. This book is a page turner - I hated to put it down, and when I had to, was back into it at every opportunity. Just sorry that I finally reached the end.
title: A page turner

author: Linda H
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2021
review_content: This novel is a roller coaster ride of action, emotion, and real science and engineering.  With the fate of earth at stake, how can one man (smart, but with flaws as all of us have) make a difference? Our hero tackles both technical and human issues as he races to solve innumerable problems.This story explains basic science and engineering across multiple disciples in terms all of us can understand as the complex plot unfolds. It is full of unexpected events and the agonizing decisions that must be made to save earth.Throughout the novel, I raced ahead to find out what would happen next, but I did not want to reach the end.  I’m ready to pre-order whatever this talented author writes next!
title: The Best Book I’ve Read in Years

author: David Wade
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2021
review_content: The Earth is endanger of freezing, because an alien parasite is taking energy from the sun.  A star that is light-years away is not affected by the parasite, so a mission is launched by the nations of the Earth.  Three team members leave, but only one survives the trip.  Ryland Grace is the world's only hope.  Grace is near the alien sun and prepares to find out why it is not affected, but then a very strange thing happens.....he encounters an alien spaceship.  It turns out the alien spaceship is there for the same reason.  There is only one survivor on the alien ship.  Grace teams up with him to solve the mystery that could doom their planets to extinction.  This was a great story.  I couldn't put it down.
title: Great story

author: Taylor Marie Corrin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2021
review_content: If I could give this book 6 stars I would because I LOVED Project Hail Mary!!! In fact, as of right now it’s my favorite book I’ve read this year. I honestly don’t think my review will do this book justice, but I will try my best.My suggestion is to go into this book as blind as possible. Try to avoid spoilers or reviews that give too much of the plot away if you can, because there are some fascinating developments that happen in this book that I am SO glad I didn’t know about until it was revealed to me as I read along. All I knew about this book going into it was the blurb, that it’s written by Andy Weir, and that some of the advanced readers were giving this book 5 stars but that was it. I didn’t read in depth on it beforehand, I just jumped right in and I am glad I did.Those of you who loved The Martian like me (it’s one of my favorite sci-fi books!) will love Project Hail Mary too, and I love both equally now. Project Hail Mary has a lot of similar elements to The Martian, yet it is still it’s own very unique story. Both books are science focused, take place in space, have some witty lines and writing, and revolve around a solitary astronaut/scientist, but from there onward the stories and concepts are very different.However, Project Hail Mary is just as expertly plotted and executed as The Martian with a main character you are rooting for from beginning to end. At times it is a wild ride and it is so compulsively readable. Project Hail Mary kept me up way past my bedtime two nights in a row because at times I just could NOT put this book down. There is a lot of cool exploration into a lot of different concepts and I actually learned quite a bit from reading this book.I thoroughly enjoyed how everything came together and the ending was SO SATISFYING! I’m not even going to talk about my favorite character because I don’t want to spoil anything, but let’s just say I appreciated that character so much (once you read the book you’ll know who I’m talking about).If I didn’t have a huge TBR stack staring at me, and if I hadn’t already promised to immediately lend my copy to my boyfriend, I would actually consider rereading this book again because I miss it already. Thankfully I had preordered my own copy so I can reread it again in the future once I've lent it out to people.Also I just found out that they’re going to turn this book into a movie. If it’s the same people who did the film version of The Martian then we’re going to be in for a treat because The Martian film is one of my favorite book to film adaptations. Let’s cross our fingers for an epic Project Hail Mary film.If you asked me whether or not I like the Martian or Project Hail Mary more, I would honestly respond that I enjoy both equally which makes me happy. It’s not often that I have two favorite books from the same author.Overall I recommend this to everyone! Even if you aren’t big into sci-fi but just love a good book, give this one a shot.
title: If I Could Give Project Hail Mary Six Stars I Would!

author: sajupuri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: What I like about Weir’s latest book, Project Hail Mary, was the focus on one main character and the solitude they felt on their journey, which was one of the main strengths of Watney in The Martian; the loneliness the character felt was communicated thoroughly. I think what separates Project Hail Mary from Weir’s other novels is the mystery surrounding the problem that the character(s) seek to solve; it was a good mix of suspense and mystery compared to the other novels that relied on mainly suspense. My favorite aspect of Project Hail Mary was the relationship Ryland forms with Rocky, which can be hilarious at times.My only very minor issue with the novel is that it certainly relies a bit more on lots of chemistry (all very relevant, course) and some of the orbital mechanics that is used isn’t explained as well as the other scientific fields are in this novel or as well as orbital mechanics are explained in Weir’s other novels.All in all, I’d say it is Weir’s more adventurous literary endeavors (covering topics from language formation to civilization building to evolution to physics) and is certainly welcome, at least by me. I highly recommend it to any science fiction fan, plain science enthusiast, or anyone who was a fan of The Martian (maybe not Artemis). Truly one of my all-time favorite books, and do not mind rereading in the future nearing the release of the rumored film adaptation.
title: Once I started this book, I could NOT stop devouring it!

author: Marvin Aberle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2021
review_content: I just finished this book today. Previously my all-time favorite science fiction book was The Moon is a Harsh Mistress by Robert Heinlein.  Now it is Hail Mary by Andy Weir. Yes, it really is that good and deserves to be in that pantheon. This book really does have everything: apocalyptic excitement, physics, microbiology, space travel, very memorable characters, and plenty of fascinating sci-fi problems that need to be solved. The Martian was an exquisite book because of the plot and accuracy of the physics portrayed. Hail Mary does this too, but adds microbiology now as well. I'm fairly well-versed in both, and I found it all exciting and plausible. There is so much here, and also plot twists that keep the blood pressure up. I cried once or twice during the book, and that doesn't really happen to me. That's how attached you become to the characters. You will never forget them. I can't recommend this book enough. Andy Weir is a science-fiction genius, and I hope he keeps working hard.

author: Patrick F. Gleason

review_content: Andy Weir's technical virtuosity in creating a compelling science fiction tale overcomes his less skillful rendering of human (and "alien") character via dialogue. author: Doud_FtC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2021
review_content: I’m only 70 pages into an almost 500 page novel, but there are already some issues that don’t jive. In The Martian and this novel, the author appears to use physics to help the protagonist unravel their conundrum. In this one it helps him (maybe a she in a future book?) determine that gravitational acceleration is too high for earth and it cannot be a centrifuge. But,1. By giving the mass and diameter of an Astrophage we find that its density (mass per unit volume) is approximately 4% of an Earth microorganism, that is, either much lighter compounds than water or a lot of empty space, except2. Puncturing an Astrophage reduces it to a blob of goop, implying it’s a liquid which isn’t consistent with its density, and3. Finding that the Astrophage is (chemically at least) mostly water. It’s also annoying that the volume of one Astrophage is so small (500 femto-liter or 0.5 times ten to the minus twelve liters) that no existing or planned analytical instrument could determine its composition.The witty repartee between the protagonist and ESA overlord is nice, but not realistic. So, engaging story line but please dot the i’s and cross the t’s.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: Science and the scientific method work on a scale of decades and centuries-- they build up a foundation on which inventions can grow.  The most spectacular of inventions take years to effect society in meaningful ways.  Andy comes up with situations where science is quick, exciting, and dangerous.  Like McGyver was to engineering, his protagonists are to science.  They hypothesize, test, deal with the consequences of being wrong, and repeat.My high school physics class we had was not taught by an inspirational figure.  Physics wasn't his thing.  He would actually have us grade each other's work.  We would then step through the solutions and note the correct answers.  In real physics, partial credit is key-- we never know the answer completely-- the important parts are in how we go about solving the problem.  Our teacher didn't understand this.There may be a technical issue or two with a small fraction of the science in Project Hail Mary.  That isn't the point.  The point is that his story might inspire critical thinkers to engage science and to dream about how their work can contribute to the survival and betterment of humanity.  So yes, 19/20, Andy Weir.
